title: Gardening Matters Community Garden Directory
name: Gardening Matters Community Garden Directory
description: An online map of community gardens across the Twin Cities and Greater Minnesota created by Gardening Matters

properties.name: 5th Street Community Garden
properties.description: 1800 5th Street South, MinneapolisBeautificationThe Fifth Street Community Garden was started in the Spring of 2006 to beautify our neighborhood and stimulate interest in a community-based project. Despite our brief existence, we’ve added some special features. The most popular is the beautiful curved brick path, an important pedestrian link in the neighborhood. Near the path is a rain garden that catches runoff from a parking lot next door. Gardeners used the left-over dirt from these projects to construct a mound planted with native prairie plants and grasses. We also built an herb garden and an area with shrubs and ornamental grasses.

properties.name: 12th and 13th Avenue Block Club Garden
properties.description: 2727 12th Ave South, MinneapolisFood Production, Youth Programming, Individual PlotsThis Midtown Phillips garden began in 1996 as a block club crime and safety initiative. Its success is linked to the success of the neighborhood. In 2001 we purchased the lot, becoming the first resident-owned community garden in Minneapolis. Three plots are tended by Anderson students, including an elevated bed for the autistic kids’ program. In 2004 we installed stone steps, allowing everyone to safely enjoy our tranquil garden. In 2005, we added garden art constructed by kids and coordinated by Victoria Pena.

properties.name: 15th Avenue North Community Garden
properties.description: 1312 15th Ave N., MinneapolisFood production, individual plotsWe are a group of 10 household who garden together in North Minneapolis.  2010 will be our third year of gardening to help supplement our groceries and build community.

properties.name: 18th Avenue Green
properties.description: 18th Avenue at E 33rd Street MinneapolisFood Production and Beautification

properties.name: 32nd Street Community Garden
properties.description: 3201 29th Avenue South, MinneapolisFood Production, Individual PlotsThe 32nd Street Community Garden has been a formal community garden since 1999 and was an informal community garden for most of the 1990s. It is in the back yard of a house which is used as a church. In 2006, a new house was built on the lot which caused the garden to be redesigned with much support from the landowner. The original garden was 20 by 80 feet with 11 small plots and the new garden will be larger (about 40 by 50 feet) and have 8 large plots. Most plot holders live within a block of the garden. No waiting list is maintained. For more information: Eric Hart at 612-722-3260 or hart3151@tcq.net

properties.name: Accord Community Garden
properties.description: Van Cleve Park-15th St & Como Ave, MinneapolisBeautificationRefresh yourself at the Accord Community Garden, located at the foot of the towering wind chime sculpture from which it gets its name. This small but unique native plant garden is a restful spot in the SE Como neighborhood, with benches overlooking the grasses and flowers. The sculpture sings a low, throaty song whenever the wind blows; even without wind, it gives a mini-concert at noon, 3:00, 6:00, and 9:00 PM. Join us every third Saturday, 10:00 – 12 noon, April through October, to work, enjoy, and learn about native plant gardening.

properties.name: Alley Cat Community Garden
properties.description: Alley between Van Buren St NE and Architect Ave, MinneapolisAlley Cat Gardens was begun in 2009 when a small group of neighbors decided to investigate the possibility of using a small      (0.15 acre) triangular lot—owned by Hennepin County—that for some years has grown only grass and volunteer plants. It is nearly unknown and invisible to all except those with property along the alley that defines the garden area and inspired its name. Current gardeners envision verdant vegetable beds, a kids’ garden area, flowering perennials and a picnic table in place by midsummer 2010. One unusual feature is the center spot, which is about three feet lower than the perimeter—we dream of creating a water garden, and we’d love ideas about how to employ the topography to learn about capturing and storing rain water.

properties.name: Andersen United Community School Earth Day Garden
properties.description: 1098 Andersen Lane, MinneapolisYouth education

properties.name: Andersen United Community School Garden
properties.description:
1098 Andersen Lane, Minneapolis
Youth
The garden started when a middle school science classroom went out to beautify the   10th Ave side of the school with a native plant garden that the whole community would enjoy.   The middle school students and some school administration are directly involved in the gardening process.   When visiting the garden, people should look at the unique colored bricks that spell out the school's name and some of the native plants that represent the nations of students in the school.   The purpose of the community garden is to beautify the school grounds and provide an opportunity for the neighborhood to showcase the wonderful talents and skills of its students.  Each year, the garden will host a beautification and re-planting party.  Come visit!

properties.name: Archdale Community Garden
properties.description: 1600 1st Ave S, MinneapolisFood Production, Youth"Putting Down Roots" art garden will create community and teach skills to youth experiencing homelessness. For an entire growing season, young people will work with resident artist to build an art garden onsite at Archdale in the underused backyard area that faces I-94. Youth experiencing homelessness will incorporate healthy eating and creativity into their daily lives.Garden Journal Public Photo Album

properties.name: The Artstop Garden
properties.description: 32nd St and Chicago Ave-SE corner, MinneapolisBeautificationIn 1991, the purchase of a corner lot by an adjoining neighbor brought The ArtStop Garden into being. Through the efforts of neighbors this bus stop lot filled with weeds, tires, broken cement, and little hope has become another symbol of revitalization in Powderhorn, a neighborhood of positive change. This peaceful garden of flowers, trees, and sculpture has been the non-violent setting for many years of creative arts activities, plantings, harvestings, and community gatherings. It is an affirming way to address the cultural diversity, pain, and assets of our neighborhood.

properties.name: Augsburg Community Garden
properties.description:
20th Avenue South at South 6th Street
Minneapolis
Food Production, Native Plantings, and Labyrinth
 
The Augsburg Community Garden is in its first full season and consists of 40 individual plots open to produce, flower, and perennial gardening.  The garden also hosts a labyrinth and native border planting.

properties.name: Aurora/ St. Anthony's Community Peace Sanctuary Garden
properties.description: 851 Aurora Avenue, St. PaulYouth Programming, Beautification, Food ProductionThe garden started in 2000 when community people started meeting and developing the proposal for the garden on a vacant lot. Today, the garden grows food and flowers, and provides a safe social environment for area students and families. The garden’s goals are to promote environmental literacy through urban gardening, and to encourage community solutions to common problems, and thereby strengthening community ties and creating positive outlets. The garden is supported by community members and students from the Unidale Area Learning Center, who gain civic and community learning in addition to academic study related to urban environmental, economic, business, community, health and social issues.

properties.name: Bancroft Community Garden
properties.description: 4101 16th Ave South, MinneapolisFood productionLocated in the SE corner of the Bancroft Neighborhood, our community gardens are a quiet place for local residents to grow vegetables, herbs and flowers.   Since 1995, the Bancroft Neighborhood Assocation has prioritized providing space for local food production.  Gardening here means interacting with the young children who sometimes play in the green space, greeting dogs and their owners and interacting with the Bethel Church community.  With a picnic bench near by, water access and bathrooms in the church, the Bancroft Community Gardens are a great place to grow food the best way possible, by hand.

properties.name: Bancroft Meridian Garden
properties.description: 1201 E 38th Street, MinneapolisYouth Programming, BeautificationThe Meridian is a large perennial garden lovingly started and maintained by neighbors and friends. Relax among our colorful blooms and butterflies while chatting with our gardeners about the Meridian's history, our plant selection and learn about our partnership with the Minneapolis Park and Recreation Board. We look forward to seeing you at the Meridian!

properties.name: Bearsville Meadow
properties.description: 2110 Orchard Lane, White Bear Lake Food Production

properties.name: The Beltrami Community Garden
properties.description: 1213 Spring Street NE, MinneapolisFood ProductionWe are filling a previously empty space with growing things that will benefit the Beltrami Neighborhood.  More plants in the community will mean more wildlife, including beautiful birds and butterflies.  Residents will also have an opportunity to become acquainted as they work in the garden.  Plot-holders also enjoy the benefit of a garden in which to grow fresh, healthy, organic fruits and vegetables.  The garden will positively impact the Beltrami Neighborhood in many ways.

properties.name: Bethany Gardens
properties.description: 7121 Bloomington Ave S, RichfieldFood production, communal gardening

properties.name: Birchwood Community Garden
properties.description: 2544 Highway 100 South, St. Louis Park, MN at Lutheran Church of the ReformationFood Production, Beautification, Community Building, and Youth EducationBirchwood Community Gardens consists of 24 plots available to neighborhood residents on the campus of Lutheran Church of the Reformation on Highway 100 South in St. Louis Park Founded in 1998, the gardens are intended to provide beauty, food production, and a meeting place for all neighborhood residents. We also plan to begin a youth gardening program in 2009. Check out the garden website here!

properties.name: Bloomington Community Garden
properties.description: 8155 Park Ave South, Bloomington Food Production Seasonal garden plots are available for rent near Smith park. The season runs from May 1 (weather permitting) through October 15 and the rental cost is $32. The plots are 10 by 15 feet and located just south of Concordia Academy, between 82nd and 83rd Streets. There is an on-site water tank for gardeners' use. The returning renters’ priority registration period closes in early April. New applications from Bloomington residents will be processed on a first-come, first-served basis mid-April. All remaining applications will be processed on a first-come, first served basis late April. During initial application processing each applicant will be limited to a maximum of 2 garden plots. If plots remain available, these will be offered to those applicants expressing interest in more than 2 garden plots (on their Garden Plot Application). Individuals will be contacted in the order listed above and given 24 hours to respond and pay for the additional rentals. After 24 hours the plot(s) may be offered to another applicant. Application and garden plot map are available here.

properties.name: Boston Scientific Hearts for Health Garden
properties.description: Innovation Way, N of County Rd. FFood donationLocated on the Arden Hills campus, the Boston Scientific Hearts for Health Garden is the first ever "giving garden" of Boston Scientific Corporation.  The garden produce and education promoting heart health awareness are provided in partnership with other community based organizations.  The garden is a place where Boston Scientific employees and their guests age 10 and older contribute through volunteerism toward these goals.   Currently delivering weekly produce donations to The Eagles' Nest, a shelter of Women of Nations, serving primarily African American and Native American women and children from domestic violence environments.

properties.name: Breen/Jones Community Garden
properties.description: 3701 Penn Ave N, MinneapolisFood production, community building, food donationAn Urban Farming community garden is a cooperative effort of neighbors and neighborhood organizations.  All food produced in the garden is available and free for people in the area who need it.   The garden serves as an outdoor community meeting place, a space for cross-cultural and intergenerational sharing, and a place for learning and sharing gardening practices.

properties.name: Brian Coyle Community Garden
properties.description: 1515 Chicago Avenue, Minneapolis, MN Drive down Chicago Ave near Hennepin County Medical Center and the Brian Coyle Community Garden is sure to Catch your eye.  The show garden is a bonanza of color during the warm summer months with poppies and marigolds and zinnias all competing for your attention.  The garden boasts 31 plots, 2 of which are raised beds, as well as a shade garden and show garden maintained by the longtime Brian Coyle community gardeners.  Created in partnership with Elliont Park Neighborhood In. and Aeon (formerly Central Community Housing Trust), this garden is a green oasis for the residents of this busy Elliot Park neighborhood.

properties.name: Bronx Park Community Garden
properties.description: 2500 Georgia Avenue, St. Louis Park Food Production

properties.name: Bryn Mawr Community Gardens (Community Landscapes)
properties.description:
Upton Ave S & Cedar Lake Rd
Bryn Mawr Minneapolis

Beautification & Community Building
 
Bryn Mawr neighbors have been greening public spaces in our neighborhood for since about 1990.  Our public spaces are not the usual community gardens of rented vegetable plots.  Rather, we plant flowers, shrubs, bulbs, trees, annuals and perennials in boulevards, planters, planting beds, pots, medians, and hillsides at the entries and central commercial nodes of our neighborhood.  In addition, we have restored a woodland within Bassett Creek Park adjacent to Bassett Creek, a creek that flows from Plymouth’s Medicine Lake to the Mississippi River.  We tend these gardens as a group and as individuals, picking up litter and weeding and watering.  It’s great exercise and a social event as well.  We hope that visitors, residents, and businesses appreciate the difference that this greening makes in the neighborhood as much as we do.   We showcase these public gardens and several private gardens during our biannual garden tour. Please join us!

properties.name: Camden Gateway Sculpture Garden
properties.description: 42nd Ave N and Lyndale Ave N, MinneapolisBeautificationThe Camden Gateway Sculpture Garden began when neighbors wanted to replace abandoned buildings with garden space. In a collaboration between gardeners, neighborhood organizations, Minneapolis and it’s Arts Council, a Minneapolis Gateway was born. Zoran Moisilov’s stone sculptures were installed in 1996 and the new Camden Garden Club offered to plant and maintain the gardens. NRP money helped purchase a watering system four years later, and the perennials and trees have flourished since. The large block-long garden is a flowing river of grass with mounds on either side representing the Mississippi River and city of Minneapolis. We are truly tied together by our river.

properties.name: Camden Housing
properties.description: 4643 Lyndale Ave N, MinneapolisFood productionThis garden serves the Camden apartments

properties.name: Cathedral Hill Homes Garden
properties.description: 280 Dayton Ave, St. Paul Youth Programming, Food Production

properties.name: Celeste's Dream Community Garden
properties.description: 1884 Randolph Ave, St. PaulEducation, Communal Food Production, Food DonationCeleste’s Dream Community Garden is sponsored by Celeste’s Dream: Spirituality for Young Adults Sisters of St. Joseph of Carondelet. Enjoy healthy produce, learn organic gardening, give to those in need and dig into the big picture. Located in the yard behind the O’Shaughenessy Auditorium. More information can be found at www.csjstpaul.org or by calling 651-696-2872.

properties.name: Central Clinic Youth Garden
properties.description: 2610 Central Ave NE, MinneapolisYouth, communal food productionThe mission of the Central Clinic Youth Garden is to cultivate healthy lifestyle choices through food, learning and community.  The garden is an intiative of FIT Force, a community-based, healthy lifestyle program of the Central Clinic, whose aim is to prevent and decrease the prevalence of obesity in youth aged 11-18 years and their caregivers by promoting healthy diets and increased use of meal planning by famlies and by encouraging youth and caregivers to participate in activities that lower resting heart rate and BMI.

properties.name: Center for Changing Lives Community Garden
properties.description: 2414 Oakland Ave S, MinneapolisCommunal Food ProductionThe CFCL Communal Garden was started in 2011 with a focus on changing lives and building community by promoting opportunities for neighbors to live healthier lifestyles.   The goals are: to increase access to affordable, healthy food for neighborhood residents and to engage residents in neighborhood events.

properties.name: Churchill Gardens
properties.description: Intersection of Horton,Van Slyke, and Churchill St, St. PaulBeautificationChurchill Community Garden was established in 1999 . Created on a barren triangle of St. Paul park property in Como Park, the garden is supported by neighbors. Churchill Community Garden consists of five perennial beds: two mixed flower gardens; a sedum and grass bed; a daffodil and day lily garden; and a garden surrounding a sign made by a neighbor. A beautiful granite boulder also adorns the grass garden. We invite you to see gardening styles that reflect our area’s diversity.

properties.name: City of Brooklyn Park Community Garden
properties.description: Eidem Farm101st Ave and Noble Parkway, Brooklyn ParkFood production

properties.name: Cobblehill Apartments Community Garden
properties.description: 2600 Cobblehill Dr, WoodburyFood Production, Beautification, Food Donation.  For residents only.

properties.name: Columbus Community Garden
properties.description: 3300 Columbus Ave S, MinneapolisFood Production, Individual PlotsColumbus Community Garden (CCG) provides a common space for neighbors to meet, grow food, and build community. The benefits of the garden extend to others as well: the garden provides green space and stabilizes the neighborhood by attracting and retaining responsible residents. It is particularly effective at connecting neighbors from diverse classes and cultures. With the help of City Garden Trust and the Trust for Public Land, CCG was able to purchase the property. CCG has played a significant role in stabilizing the surrounding neighborhood since it first began as a block club project in 1990.

properties.name: Common Ground Community Garden
properties.description: 5151 & 5159 Newton Ave N, MinneapolisBeautification, Food Production, Individual plots

properties.name: Community Design Center-1288 Forest Street Garden
properties.description: 1288 Forest Street, St. PaulYouth Programming, Beautification, Food ProductionThe Community Design Center of Minnesota started in 1969 as a non-profit corporation. In 1996 we established a children's garden project on the East Side of St. Paul. Today our Youth Enterprise in Food and Ecology Program includes a Garden Corps, a Conservation Corps, environmental science learning activities, and cooking/nutritionOver 40 youth participate in our Garden and Conservation Corps. They plant, maintain, and harvest seven gardens; operate a Salad Share CSA(29 members) and three farmer's markets; create and sell garden-related products; build rain gardens; and help restore the Bruce Vento Nature Sanctuary.  Community Design Center Gardens won the SIlver Bloom award for outstanding environmental garden,  as well as the Silver Bloom award for outstanding community vegetable garden from the City of St Paul and St Paul Garden Club in 2005. Ruth Murphy, the organization's executive director was awarded the Gardening Advocate Award from the City of St Paul and St Paul Garden Club in 2005.

properties.name: Community Peace Garden
properties.description: Hwy 94 and Cedar Ave, MinneapolisHorticultural Therapy, Beautification, Food Production, Individual PlotsOur garden is special because immigrants and seniors are the majority of our gardeners: gardening maintains their health and provides a sense of belonging to the community. Not only do the gardeners get to eat the vegetables they produce, but they also work and socialize with other community members.

properties.name: Como Corner Community Garden
properties.description: 1000 22nd Ave SE, MinneapolisBeautificationComo Corner Community Garden is definitely not its usual self these days. Despite the BNSF Bridge rebuild that occupies half the site, gardeners are working the soil! Started in 1992 by volunteers who converted this previously weedy and unbuildable lot to a volunteer-supported “park” and restful bus stop where pedestrians and bikers find respite on its bench.

properties.name: Cool Community Gardens
properties.description: 1601 4th St SE, Austin MNFood productionFood gadrening is good for everyone.  At Cool Community Gardens, our goal is to see everyone in Austin and Mower County eating some healthy, locally grown, chemical-free food most of the year.  Everyone who has a desire can grow a portion of their groceries.  Recruiting adults, school-age children and their families, clubs and organizations who want to grow for themselves plus a little more to give away.  Team Gardening is encouraged!  Join our newsletter list to find out about events, food preservation classes and recipes: GardenNetwork2011@gmail.com

properties.name: Cornercopia Student Organic Farm at the UMN
properties.description: Cleveland Ave & Larpenteur Ave, Falcon Heights Food Production.

properties.name: Cowern Community Garden
properties.description: Margaret St N and Eldridge Ave E, North St. Paul Food production and donation The Cowern Community Garden is located in North St. Paul at the intersection of Margaret St N and Eldridge Ave E in an organic orchard and habitat area. A portion of the orchard has been re-purposed to include the 6800 square foot garden which includes 23 individual 10x10 plots as well as a communal plot that is 1725 square feet. Gardeners in the communal plot will donate approximately 60% of the harvest locally and split the remaining 40% among themselves. The garden is fenced and has water. The Cowern Community Garden is sponsored by School District 622 Community Education. Please visit the garden website at www.isd622.org/communitygarden or call 651-748-7437

properties.name: Dodge Nature Center Family Garden
properties.description: 1701 Charlton St, West St PaulEducation, Individual PlotsThe Dodge Nature Center Community Garden has existed in various forms since the 1960’s. It began as a teaching garden and evolved into a community garden. Since we are joined with a nature center, ecologically friendly gardening is part of our mission and the garden is managed using organic methods. On-site compost for fertilizer and straw mulch are available to gardeners. It has thirty-five 15’x 15’ plots available and is open during daylight hours. The garden generally draws from and serves the communities of West St Paul, St Paul’s west side, and Mendota Heights.

properties.name: Dowling Community Garden
properties.description: 46th Avenue at 39th Street, MinneapolisYouth programming, Food Production, Food Donation, Individual plots Dowling Community Garden began in 1943 when subsistence gardens were planted during World War II and is one of two known "Victory Gardens" remaining in the U.S. Dowling contains over 180 plots, serving more than 250 gardeners. Dowling's special focus is preserving older varieties of fruits, vegetables and flowers through educational outreach and seed-saving. We offer an heirloom plant sale in May, present Heirloom Festival in August, maintain a demonstration garden and contribute seeds to international seed-saving organizations. We distribute produce to food shelves, and have installed flower gardens for the community to enjoy. Come visit us! www.DowlingCommunityGarden.orgDowling Community Garden has won two awards: Minnesota State Horticultural Society's 2003 award for "Excellence in Community Vegetable Gardening" and 2006 first place winner for Minneapolis Blooms.

properties.name: Dunedin Terrace Community Garden

The garden's renters for the 2010 season are diverse in age, gender, culture, geographical location of residency, and they are all interested in gardening!

properties.name: Eleanor Graham Community Garden

In 2007, A restoration process was started to care for our two ancient oaks and to groom the common space, making the garden a destination and community gathering place. In addition, the garden was gifted with five fruit trees -- plum, cherry and apricot -- and also sports a newly planting flower bed around our sign at the entrance to the garden.   The garden received a CURA grant, so that a UMN graduate student assisted us in a redesign project!

properties.name: Emily Peake Memorial Garden
properties.description: 1900 block of 3rd Ave S, MinneapolisYouth Programming, Horticultural Therapy, Beautification, Food Production, Food Donation, Individual PlotsEmily Peake Memorial Garden (est. 1995) was originally a perennial garden dedicated to neighborhood Native American activist and peacemaker Emily Peake. In 2001 neighborhood interest grew, and today it supports thirteen community gardeners in an intimate nature bordered by perennial and flower beds.

properties.name: The English Learning Center Student Farm
properties.description: 2320 Elliot Ave S., MinneapolisFood ProductionThe English Learning Center Farm is a communal garden space run by ELC staff, volunteers, students and their families. It is located in the yard of the Our Saviour’s Housing’s Transitional House, directly behind the English Learning Center. Garden volunteers help students learn to garden in Minnesota, while also practicing conversational English skills. The intent is both to increase the food security of our students, while also providing English language practice and an activity for learners to put on a job application. Plans are in the works for an end of season Harvest Party, and the development of a formalized work-readiness component for future seasons.

properties.name: FairShare Farm

properties.name: Falcon Heights Community Garden

Located in Community Park (at Roselawn & Cleveland), the garden consists of 20 individual plots, in which members may grow vegetables, flowers, herbs, and neighborly relationships. With Falcon Heights' large number of apartment/townhome dwellers, and many home lots blessed with mature shade trees (but not a lot of garden sunshine!), the garden provides a much needed resource to our city. We welcome gardeners and visitors of all ages and backgrounds, and hope to continue making a positive impact in our community.

"Garden of Eden" will establish a community garden for many members and volunteers of the neighborhood's children, youth, parents and grandparents to cultivate and share vegetables, fruits, mutual love, care and understanding.
Our community garden will be the center point of reaching out to the community at large, connecting each other and enhancing the diversity of our community. 
We have a BIG DREAM for our community garden!

properties.name: Garden of Nations
properties.description: 4147 7th St NE, Columbia HeightsFood ProductionGarden of Nations started in 2010, when the Economic Development Authority of the City of Columbia Heights gave Grace Lee permission to use an empty residental lot ot make a community garden.   The vision of Garden of Nations is to build community and cultural understanding by bringing together diverse neighbors.   We have Caucasian, Korean, Ecuadorian and Iraqui gardeners.  Through the Garden of Nations, neighbors who live within a few houses of each other and had never met have met, shared a meal, and worked in the garden together.  Our garden is communal with everyone sharing in the labor and produce.  We also hope to bring in kids from the local elementary school for a fall field trip to show kids what is possible when neighbors of diverse backgrounds come together

properties.name: Garden Party on Elm Drive
properties.description: 200 block of Elm Drive, Apple ValleyFood ProductionGarden Party on Elm Drive was established as a community development project started by four neighborhood families.    The unique feature of our garden is that it is a "distributed community garden".   Each family has dedicated all or a portion of their garden to the community.  We haev had planning meetings to decide who will grow what, as well as to create plans of support to keep our gardens growing.   We plan to distribute produce throughout our neighborhood and community.  We have a few events scheduled for this gardening community, including a salsa day and a canning day.

properties.name: Gateway Community Garden
properties.description: SW corner of 12th Ave SE & E Hennepin Ave, MinneapolisBeautificationThe “Gateway Community Garden,” named because it is the “gateway” to the SE Como neighborhood, has joined University students, elderly residents, and young children since its inception in 2002. Through the efforts and donations of neighbors, SECIA staff, MN Green, and the Tree Trust, the site has been transformed to an award-winning and beloved community garden. We gather here for garden nights, ice-cream socials, and National Night Out parties where garden art projects often occur. Our goals are to beautify the neighborhood, give traffic a reason to pause, and inspire neighbors to slow down and connect.

properties.name: Gateway Trail Community Garden
properties.description: 300 Arlington Avenue at Mississippi Street St. Paul Food Production, Beautification, Community Building, and Youth Education The Gateway Trail Community Garden is a cooperative effort of neighbors in the upper Payne Phalen neighborhood started in 2009 with generous contributions made by the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources, the Gateway Trail Association and the Payne Phalen District 5 Planning Council. The pergola that welcomes people to the entrance of our garden was built by the DNR and the art tiles on it were made by students at the Mississippi Creative Arts Magnet School. Please see our blog at http://gatewaytrailgarden.wordpress.com/ for more information on the garden or stop by while walking or biking the Gateway Trail!

properties.name: Glendale Community Garden
properties.description: 96 St. Mary's Ave SE, MinneapolisFood productionThe Glendale Community Garden provides gardening opportunities for Glendale Townhomes residents.  Many residents are experienced gardeners and others are involved with the Urban Gardener educational program at Glendale.   This garden provides space and resources to committed gardeners.

properties.name: Graham Place
properties.description: 1745 W Graham, St. PaulFood production, community building, donationAn Urban Farming community garden is a cooperative effort of neighbors and neighborhood organizations.  All food produced in the garden is available and free for people in the area who need it.   The garden serves as an outdoor community meeting place, a space for cross-cultural and intergenerational sharing, and a place for learning and sharing gardening practices.

properties.name: Grassy Knoll Garden
properties.description:
16th Ave NE & Johnson St NE, Minneapolis
Beautification
 
Grassy Knoll Garden at 16th Ave NE and Johnson St NE in Minneapolis is a work in progress that had been left idle for 12 years.  The site contained many hazardous chemicals which are still buried under the Grassy Knoll. Perennial flower gardens and a grove of native trees have been planted. The trees continue to remediate the soil.  This May a beautiful garden trellis sculpture called "Wind in the Trees" was erected. Our goal is the beautification, remediation, and re-treeing of the neighborhood with the Grassy Knoll as a focal point.

properties.name: Green Friends
properties.description: 4036, 4040, 4044, 4048, 4052 45th Aveune South, MinneapolisBeautificationMary Ann heard about MN Green through another friend and in 2009 talked to some of her neighbors about the possibility of joining so that we can plant flowers in our adjoining boulevards.  In 2009 4 families participated.  This year we have 5 but 2 others across the street wanted to join but we thought it would be too difficult to manage 7 households.  They will either join our group next year or start their own group with other neighbors on their side of the street.  We help each other plant our gardens and learn from each other as well.  Several neighbors have asked us about our gardens so we get to share the joy of gardening with others and encourage them to do similar gardening projects.

properties.name: Green Pride Garden
properties.description: 1070 Greenbrier St, St PaulFood ProductionThe Green Pride Garden is located on St. Paul's East Side.  It was converted from a vacant lot in 2010 to provide a place for our neighbors to grow their own food.   We have 12 plots in our lovely, sunny garden.

properties.name: Greenvale Community Garden
properties.description: 700 Lincoln Parkway Northfield, MN Food Production, Food Donation, Beautification, & Community Building Located on the grounds of Greenvale Park Elementary School, the Greenvale Park Community Garden has 32 plots for individuals and families to grow food and flowers, and two plots for elementary school classrooms and other youth organizations. The Greenvale Community Garden also has a communally tended “Sharing Plot” where we grow food for the Northfield Food Shelf. The Garden is a collaboration between Northfield Community Gardeners, Northfield Public Schools Community Services Division, and Greenvale Park Elementary.

properties.name: Guardian Angels Church Food Shelf Garden
properties.description: Guardian Angels Church, 8260 Fourth St N, Oakdale Food donation Established in 1995, Guardian Angels Food Shelf Garden is a ministry of the church guided by a committee that manages a 3/4 acre site on parish grounds where a variety of fruits and vegetables are grown for others in need. The harvest is donated to three community food shelves in the east metro area on a weekly basis from mid June through mid October. People are invited to join us as we work together to care for those struggling to meet basic needs. Gardening sessions begin in May on Saturday and Tuesday mornings and Thursday evenings. More info at the website.

properties.name: Hancock Science Inquiry Garden
properties.description: 1599 Englewood Ave, St. PaulYouth focusThe Hancock Science Inquiry Garden is an outdoor teaching tool used by the students at Hancock Elementary. They learn about eco-systems, plants, lifecycles, food, nutrition, and simple botany, among other relevant topics. Many of the projects are student-generated and implemented, creating a sense of ownership and a positive legacy.

properties.name: Harvest Gardens
properties.description: SW corner of Co Rd C and Hazelwood St, MaplewoodFood productionFirst Evangelical Free Church in Maplewood (we call ourselves ‘First Free’) purchased 16 acres in 2004 for future facility expansion. In 2009 a portion was set aside for community gardens, called Harvest Gardens. In 2010 approximately 150 gardeners used 3.5 acres, and in 2011 we plan to expand to about 6 acres.The congregation is grateful to God for the land, and wants to share it with the community. The gardens are organized by volunteers and financed by donations. Garden plots are 15 ft x 15 ft. Water is available. Many gardeners are from the Hmong community. All are welcome!Check out our website at www.harvestgardens.org

properties.name: Hawthorne Neighborhood Garden
properties.description: 2826 North Fourth St. MinneapolisFood Production, Community Building, Individual PlotsHawthorne Neighborhood Garden sits on the site of a former crack house demolished around 1995. Neighbors fought city hall for years to establish this lot as an official community garden; we succeeded in 2002, when ownership passed from MCDA to the Sustainable Resource Center. The lot is 41’ X 150’ and contains vegetable and flower beds, lawns, and a few follies; about a dozen neighbors participate. Enter through the front gate—if you can find it under the grape vines. A few plots are available each year for experienced or amateur gardeners (assigned on a first-come basis).

properties.name: Heritage Park Community Garden
properties.description: 718 Aldrich Ave N, MinneapolisCommunal food productionWe are a community garden focused on food production and community building.  Our gardeners consist of Heritage Park residents, and we come from a variety of backgruonds.  We work together to maintain a communal plot containing many types of vegetables, herbs and fruits.

properties.description: 2400 Highland Drive, BurnsvilleFood ProductionHighland Drive Community Garden is located on the grounds of Open Circle Church in Burnsville, MN.  We have 20 10x10 plots that include individual gardens, a food shelf garden, and a youth garden.   Any open plots are available in March and we welcome gardeners of all backgrounds and abilities.   We have a lovely setting on a hill with ample parking, convenient water and a space to sit by other projects such as a prairie restoration and a rain garden.

properties.name: I-94 and Dowling Community Garden
properties.description: I-94 and Dowling Avenue North, MinneapolisBeautificationThe southbound ramp at I-94 and Dowling in North Minneapolis is a Camden Garden Club site designed and planted as a Japanese garden in 1998. It was remodeled in 2005 to be more carefree; Garden Club members and MNDOT personnel volunteered over two weekends to prep the soil, transplant thyme, and install 200 bushes and trees including Japanese Tree Lilac, Swiss Stone Pine, Tinkerbelle Korean Lilac, Autumn Magic Glossy Black Chokeberry and Goldflame Spirea. The garden’s focal points are weeping spruce and cherry trees and a stone turtle sunning itself in a bed of thyme and sedum.

properties.name: Jardin Paraiso Comunidad/Paradise Community Garden
properties.description: 3405 Chicago Ave S, MinneapolisCommunal food production, beautificationJardin Paraiso Communidad or Paradise Community Garden at 34th and Chicago in S. Minneapolis is a collaboration of Mujeres en Accion y Poder, PPNA, and interested neighbors.  We work together to grow vegetables and flowers, share the joy of gardening and healthy food with our children, strengthen the community, embrace culturally-specific gardening methods, develop leadership, and implement a design created by local horticulture students.  Our leadership team soruces free or low-cost materials and community talent to realize this project, so that finances will not be a barrier to participation.  Our language differences present a rewarding opportunity.  We are committed to developing leadership and to encouraging participation by all.  We value and affirm the rich diversity of our Powderhorn community.         Jardin Paraiso Comunidad o Paradise Community Garden (3405 Avenida Chicago, Minneapolis) fue formado de una colaboracion de Mujeres en Acion y Poder, PPNA, y vecinos interesados.  Trabajamos juntos a cultivar a verduras y flores, compartir la alegria de horticultura y alimento sano con nuestros ninos, fortalizar la comunidad, abrazar metodos de horticultura culturalmente especificos, desarrollar el liderazgo, y implementar un diseno creado por estudiantes de horticultura locales.   Nuestro equip de liderazgo es inventivo en buscar materiales gratis o economicos y tener acceso a talentos de comunidad para realizar este proyecto, de modo que las finanzas no sean una barrera a la participacion.  Nuestras diferencias de lengua presentan una opportunidad provechosa.   Somos dedicados a desarrollar liderazgo y a animar la participacion de todos.  Valoramos y afirmamos la diversidad rica de nuestra comunidad Powderhorn.

properties.name: Jordan Community Garden
properties.description: 1722 26th Avenue North, MinneapolisBeautification, Education, Food ProductionEstablished in 2002, the Jordan Community Garden has beautified the neighborhood, promoted cross-cultural interaction, connected youth with their food source, provided a watchful eye, and demonstrated landscaping possibilities. Located in a vacant lot on the corner of a drug dealing corridor, the garden is a powerful sign of community. The Jordan Area Community Council purchased the lot from the city (for $1). Plantings focus on native perennials, and one-third of the garden is vegetables. The garden has a meeting area and several donated fixtures. Neighborhood kids painted a sign; artists donated metal sculptures and a peace pole.

properties.name: JD Rivers' Children's Garden
properties.description: Glenwood Ave. & Washburn Ave. N. in MinneapolisThe Minneapolis Park and Recreation Board owns, operates and programs the one-acre JD Rivers’ Children’s Garden located in Theodore Wirth Park. Since 1982 the garden has provided programs focused on food production with children and teens, horticulture therapy, and intergenerational programming with recent immigrants. Garden plots are assigned to youth participating in on-site summer programs. Youth participants also engage in hands-on environmental education programs such as insect safaris, birding, water quality education, fishing, and much more. Visit www.minneapolisparks.org for more information on summer programs and garden plots.

properties.name: JT Blaisdell Community Garden
properties.description: 2609 Blaisdell Ave S, MinneapolisYouth Programming

properties.name: Kaleidoscope Garden
properties.description: 2504 Columbus Ave S, MinneapolisYouth Programming, Individual PlotsFor over ten years, the Children’s Garden in Residence (CGR) has been a joint program of the University of Minnesota Landscape Arboretum, Messiah Lutheran Church, and Kaleidoscope Kids’ Place.   Supported by private donations, CGR connects inner-city children ages 6-12 with their own gardens. During the program, children learn about gardening and the role plants play in people's lives. Graduates may apply for a variety of garden-based summer jobs as members of the CityFresh team.

properties.name: Kids Cook! Loring Schoolyard Garden
properties.description: 2600 44th Ave N (south of Loring School at Thomas Avenue and 44th Avenue N) Youth Programming, Individual PlotsGardens welcome students and their families, teachers and the community to Loring Elementary school. Two butterfly beds and a shade garden were planted in 2004. This same year Kids Cook began as an after-school enrichment program for 4th and 5th grade students. The Kids Cook curriculum inspires students to cook and explore fresh, nutritious ingredients, and to learn where our food comes from. In 2006 Kids Cook planted vegetables, herbs, and berry patch. The students and their families, the neighborhood and community have cultivated this garden. Together we celebrate with gardening and potluck garden picnics made with the produce from the garden. A native prairie was planted in 2007. We hope many lessons sprout from our garden!

properties.name: Kingfield Community Garden - Pleasant Site
properties.description: 3754 Pleasant Ave S., Minneapolis Food production After a year of dreaming and planning, 2010 is the inaugural year for the Kingfield Community garden. Our first site, the Pleasant Ave site, is on the grounds of the Center for Performing Arts. We hope to share food, ideas and work, and to strengthen our community. We appreciate the support of Kingfield neighbors, volunteers, students from Pilgrim Lutheran School, and the Kingfield Neighborhood Association. We host a Kingfield garden tour and other special events.

An Urban Farming community garden is a cooperative effort of neighbors and neighborhood organizations.  All food produced in the garden is available and free for people in the area who need it.   The garden serves as an outdoor community meeting place, a space for cross-cultural and intergenerational sharing, and a place for learning and sharing gardening practices.

properties.name: LaSalle Community Garden
properties.description: 1800 block of LaSalle Ave, MinneapolisYouth Programming, Horticultural Therapy, Beautification, Food Production, Food Donation, Individual PlotsLaSalle Community Gardens were created in 1997 from two empty lots supporting nothing but drug deals, littering, and loitering. With the help of Stevens Square and Urban Lands, volunteers planned the foundation, hauled the soil and manure, planted trees and perennials, and turned an eyesore into a place of beauty and edibles. Today the gardens support forty gardeners and showcase unique architectural elements including an aqueduct and water wheel system, a half shade structure, and Zen pathways. Each garden has its own personality, featuring vegetable plots, communal beds with native plants, and an herb wheel.

properties.name: LifeGARDEN
properties.description: Lord of Life Lutheran Church, 7401 County Road 101, Maple GroveFood production and donationLifeGARDEN occupies 1 1/2 acres on the northeast side of Lord of Life, between Country Road 101 and the church's outbuildings. One-half of the area contains 160 individual plots, each 10'x10', which are available for a maintenance fee of $25 per growing season. Sections of individual plots are designated for organic gardening, non-organic gardening, and a mixed area. The remaining 3/4 acre consists of fields devoted to a communal mission garden, with all produce being donated to CROSS, the local food shelf. Last year we donated nearly 4 tons of food. Visit our website at lordoflife.org/lifegarden (website still in progress)

properties.name: Lincoln School Peace Garden
properties.description: Penn Ave N and 12th Ave N, Minneapolis Youth programming, Beautification Started five years ago by Becca Brackett near the Lincoln School as a beautification and peace garden. Students from Lincoln have been involved on and off for the last few years, coming out to the garden to learn about plants, food, and gardening. The school has since closed, but the garden remains. This is a community garden, so all are welcome and encouraged to help out! Contact Becca if interested and we’ll get you plugged in.

properties.name: Lind Community Garden
properties.description: SE Corner of 51st Ave South and Dupont Ave S in Minneapolis Food Production, Youth Education, and Beautification   Experience a diverse collection of people and plants in our garden of raised beds on the north side of Minneapolis. Our accomplishments are evident from mid-May May through the end of October.   The garden started out as neighborhood space for a variety of cultures for food production. As the garden grew, two additional perks became apparent, including student/teacher experiences with local schools and the beautification of an open space which was being overrun by weeds.

properties.name: Lyndale Neighborhood Rain Garden
properties.description: 102 W 32nd St, Minneapolis Youth Programming, Beautification, Education The Lyndale Community Rain Garden began in 2005 when the Lyndale Neighborhood Environment Committee decided to preserve a community space and showcase sustainable landscaping.   The Committee leased property from the Lyndale Neighborhood Development Corporation and residents restored 3,000 square feet of an existing garden that now features a demonstration rain garden.   A neighborhood water quality initiative funded through the Mississippi Watershed Management Organization helped to complete the restoration.   Visitors can learn about gardening as part of an ecological system showcasing native plantings, low-mow grass, rain barrels, and composting. Our garden prevents 56,000 gallons of water from entering the stormwater system!

properties.name: Midtown Greenway Rainwater Garden Project - East Phillips
properties.description: 28th Street and the Midtown Greenway, MinneapolisBeautification -- a project of the Midtown Greenway Coalition This project is made possible through a grant from the Mississippi Watershed Management Organization. Over 160 volunteers participated in prepping, planting, maintaining and watering the gardens for the past three years. A total of 2,071 hours! All of the gardens take advantage of stormwater drainage either from the trails, or by a near by surface parking lot or roof. We are committed to using plants native to this region. Site plans are available for each garden. Please contact us to request a copy or to become a Greenway Garden Steward and help us maintain these gardens in the future.

properties.name: Midway Greenspirit Garden
properties.description: Pierce Butler and Hamline Ave, St. PaulBeautification, Food Production, Food Donation, Individual PlotsLocated in the Hamline-Midway area, our community garden is about growing relationships. Since 2003, our garden has sought to increase the connections among community members and counteract isolation. We believe that by coming together cooperatively over the garden, we strengthen our community. Vegetable gardening is a means to this end. In addition to bringing together individual gardeners, we reach out to the community to provide education, opportunities for service, and a gathering place for other organizations. We beautify our community by creating a garden that satisfies both our stomachs and our eyes.

properties.name: Minnehaha Avenue Community Garden
properties.description: 3128 Minnehaha Avenue, Minneapolis Education, Food Production, Individual Plots Minnehaha Avenue Community Garden (est. 1997) is a garden in the Longfellow Neighborhood providing 20 9X9-foot plots for those who want to grow their own vegetables or flowers but lack the space or sunlight.  We seek to build community within our garden, through potlucks, planning meetings, and work parties, and between our garden and the neighborhood, through public events.  We have many ongoing projects to which gardeners may contribute, including site beautification, on-site composting, promotion of pollinators, and neighborhood outreach.

properties.name: Minnesota Internship Center Charter High School Garden
properties.description: 310 East 38th St, MinneapolisYouthIn the upcoming school year, one of the major goals of the Minnesota Internship Center (MNIC) is to promote locally-grown and nutritious eating in the classroom and cafeteria.   To support this initiative, MNIC students and staff planted a community garden this past summer in a plot located near school property.  While the garden started as as mall project with the limited summer school students and staff, its success in showing students where and how to produce food inspired us to extend the project into the fall.   In the upcoming fall semester, MNIC plans to build a "hoop house" (quick house or low tunnel) over the school garden.  Constructed with electrical conduit pipes and plastic sheets, a hoop house captures the warmth of the sun and protects crops from harsh winter weather.  By sheltering plants from cold temperatures and harsh precipitation, MNIC would greatly extend the growing season, and thus impact, of the school garden with a hoop house.

properties.name: Minnesota Women Suffrage Garden
properties.description: Cedar Ave & Martin Luther King Blvd, St. PaulBeautification

properties.name: Mulberry Junction
properties.description: 22rd Ave NE and California St NE, MinneapolisYouth Programming, Beautification, Food Production, Food Donation, Individual plotsTucked away in a quiet corner of NE Mpls, Mulberry Junction Community Garden was established in 1996 by artists from the adjacent California Building. Our garden land is slated for development, but the garden was spared by the bulldozers for another year. The grassy picnic circle is a peaceful spot to enjoy our mature perennial and native gardens. Rocks and bricks from a former building trace the boundaries of thirty-five vegetable plots tended by a diverse array of gardeners.

properties.name: MULCH (Macalester Urban Land and Cmty Health)
properties.description: 194 Vernon St, just west of the Macalester campus between Princeton and St Clair in St. PaulBeautification, Food ProductionMULCH (Macalester Urban Land & Community Health) was established in 1995 by the MULCH student organization supporting a student run community garden at Macalester College. MULCH acts as a first introduction to community gardening and offers an education for students on where their food comes from, how it is grown and helps build community among students, faculty, staff and the neighborhood. This is an especially significant year for MULCH as the garden moved to a new location bordering the language houses at Macalester. All are welcome to come see the new community garden space that has a larger presence in the surrounding community, and is incorporating permaculture techniques. We hope to nurture this space for another 10 years like the old site!

properties.name: Mustard Seed Community Garden
properties.description: 3620 E. 26th St. MinneapolisFood production, beautification, community building, donationThe Mustard Seed Community Garden was established in the spring of 2009. Our vision for the Mustard Seed Community Garden is that it would serve the following functions:-Provide an avenue for the development of relationships between the people in the Seward community.-Provide an opportunity for people to grow their own vegetables or flowers locally.-Provide a means of blessing our lower income neighbors through the use of garden plots and by giving produce to food shelves in our community.-Provide an adornment an esthetically beautiful garden and as a sign of the love and kindness toward our neighborhood.Gardeners are involved the planning and running of this garden. We also have scheduled workdays, to work on and clean up the garden together. Gardeners have shared duties to maintain our garden.

properties.name: Nawayee Community Garden
properties.description:
2421 Bloomington Ave S. Minneapolis
Youth, Food Production
 
Nawayee community garden was established in 2007 through a grant from General Mills via the Healthy Nations Program. Students and staff at the school are mainly involved with the garden but we have a few neighbors who come by and help. What is fun about the garden is that it is always changing. It is a work in progress and we are always trying to come up with ideas to teach skills while improving upon it. This spring we are working on completing a cedar fence the students began last fall. We are also making signs and garden stones, and hope to make a simple bench or two. On the wall over looking the garden is a mural that the students created with the help of two local artists.

properties.name: New Life Community Garden
properties.description:
Plymouth Avenue at 23rd Avenue North, Minneapolis 
Community Building, Food Production, Food Donation, Youth and Family Education
<u></u> 

Our mission is to foster community engagement, healthy living and eating within the North Minneapolis area. We intend to accomplish this by using community involvement and assistance in caring for the garden, community classes on how to cultivate a successful produce garden and how to use the produce/herbs from the garden, and providing social programs including produce distribution days of giving food to families in the community.

properties.name: North End Community Garden
properties.description: Lowry Ave and Penn Ave N., MinneapolisFood ProductionThe North End Community Garden is about to begin its very first growing season (2010). Late last summer, the use of a vacant plot of land was donated by Darryl Weivoda, owner of the nearby North End Hardware Store. While still recruiting members, the garden has a strong base of support and enthusiasm that is excited to build community and begin the season. Our garden will feature a communally planted flower garden at the front, a large communal vegetable garden for donations in the middle, and 24 individual plots. Our hope is to grow: food, community, flowers, beauty, and friendship.

properties.name: Park View Montessori Community Garden
properties.description: 252 Upton Ave S MinneapolisYouth & Family Education, Community Building, Food Production & DonationThe Park View Montessori Community Garden was started in 2009 by Park View PTSA members as a way to build community and food education in the community.PTSA members, Bryn Mawr, and Harrison community members tend the garden.The garden was designed to be a part of the students’ education and currently is developing into a Cook’s Garden after-school program with garden produce.  In addition, the garden is meant to provide access to fresh, healthful food, to a diverse community while promoting knowledge of local food systems and food production.  In the spring, seedlings are sold to raise money to purchase supplies; throughout summer and fall, the community is invited to share in the harvest.

properties.name: Patrick Henry Oak Savanna Garden
properties.description: 4320 Newton Ave N, MinneapolisYouth Programming, Food DonationThe Patrick Henry Oak Savanna Garden has continued to grow to meet the needs of the local community. Partcampus/community garden, the Patrick Henry Oak Savanna now serves as a food production plot garden serving the needs oflocal Hmong familes, The garden also acts as a demonstration garden, presenting a snapshot of this native Minnesota plantcommunity, once occupying this Twin Cities area, where prairie met big woods. There is also a newly planted orchard in thecourtyard of the school. Designed and maintained by the students of Patrick Henry, this garden is part of a larger neighborhood effort to beautify and restore public spaces.

properties.name: Peace Haven
properties.description: 1601 Glenwood Ave N, MinneapolisBeautification and community building

properties.name: Phalen Poetry Park
properties.description: 987 Ivy Avenue, St. PaulBeautification Phalen Poetry Park is a small, almost hidden, community garden sponsored by the East Side Arts Council. It is playfully designed as a sleepy dragon whose spikes of feather reed grass encircle a dry pebble pond where children hop from stone to stone. Benches cast in the shape of open books invite contemplation and enjoyment of the plantings. A path winds to both the Poetry Post, a sculptural piece featuring local poets and students, and to the Marimba Benches, welcoming you to tap out a tune. The garden can be easily accessed from the parking lot of the Phalen Recreation Center, 1000 Wheelock Parkway.

properties.name: Phalen Village Community Garden of District 2
properties.description: Maryland and Hazelwood, St. PaulFood Production, Individual PlotsThe Phalen Village Community Garden is a well-known vegetable garden tended by Southeast Asian and Hmong residents. Established in 1997 on land donated by the National Guard Armory, the garden has increased participation in the neighborhood. The Armory shares responsibility for the annual lease agreement with the District 2 Council. There are fifty-three individual plots where gardeners grow vegetables to keep, sell at the farmer’s market, or donate to food shelves. Our garden features unusual vegetables that would be interesting for others to learn about. We encourage people to tour our garden to share information about foods and culture.

properties.name: Pilot Knob Community Garden
properties.description: 1436 Lone Oak Rd, EaganYouthThe Pilot Knob Elementary Community Garden was started in the spring of 2010.  We were fortunate to receive a SHIP grant from the State of Minnesota to promote healthy lives.  The start up money allowed us to create a committee and with parent help build 17 raised garden beds.  Parents, students and teachers at Pilot Knob Elementary volunteer their time to plant, weed and harvest the garden.  In the spring of 2010, kindergarten through 4th grade students planted an assortment of vegetables and herbs.  And many of the students were able to harvest and eat a crop of radishes that they planted in the spring.  Over the summer months parents and community members volunteered to tend the garden over the summer months (water, weed, harvest and plant…).  The garden is unique because it has truly been a labor of love for many people.  It has also brought the school community closer together.  On special garden days we will have 20 – 30 students and parents helping in the garden.  We also allow anyone to come and harvest vegetables and herbs whenever they like.  Over the summer we donated fresh lettuce and other vegetables to the Eagan Resource Center Food Shelf.The mission of the Pilot Knob Garden is to teach students about where food comes from and plant life cycles.  Plus,  hopefully students will acquire new tastes and appreciate fresh herbs and vegetables.  We have hosted a couple of garden events this year.  Our first event was to build the garden boxes, add soil and plant the seeds.  Then we had another events to help weed, harvest and plant new seeds.   We also used our garden lettuce at our school graduation party last spring and at our fall kindergarten picnic.  Other exciting garden news includes having the “Family Handyman Magazine” build a beautiful garden shed that we will use to store our tools and get a start on early season planting indoors.

properties.name: Pine River-Backus Community Garden
properties.description: CR-42 and Murray Ave, Pine River Food Production The Community Garden project was formed as a result of a community visioning event. Community members then formed a task force which worked to create the Pine River-Backus Community Garden. The 145x180 fenced-in garden space is located on the school grounds. Students take charge of the 60x30 community plot which donates its produce to the area food shelf and school lunch program. The remainer of the space is divided into 15x15 plots for individual/family use. There are regularly scheduled educational classes for beginning gardeners to partake in throughout the growing season. The purpose of the garden is to establish a chemical-free public garden space; to make gardens available to people of all ages and income levels, as participants and beneficiaries; to provide a space for food production; to connect the local food shelf and school to fresh local produce; to foster a sense of community and develop a public gathering place through gardening and garden related events; and to provide educational opportunities to learn about agriculture in an interactive garen environment.

properties.name: Pleasant Avenue Community Garden
properties.description: 3518 Pleasant Ave. S., Minneapolis Horticultural Therapy, Beautification, Food ProductionThe Pleasant Avenue Garden is located on a normal city lot that at 3518 Pleasant Ave. S. in the Lyndale Neighborhood of South Minneapolis.  The lot is owned by the Lyndale Neighborhood Association and organized by the gardeners who work the land.  27 individual plots are available for annual rent of $10-$25 each.  Plots range in size from 5 x10 feet to15 x 20 feet and are either in partial sun or mostly shade.  Most plots are used for food or flower production.  The garden does not allow pesticides or mineral fertilizers and has a compost bin.  Water is available.

properties.name: Prairie Oaks Community Garden
properties.description: 2600 Oakland Ave, MinneapolisFood ProductionThe Prairie Oaks Community Garden is a small space for townhouse residents to come out and enjoy locally grown food for its beauty and bounty. This is a unique space available for townhouse residents and the immediate surrounding community.

properties.name: Shoreham Community Garden
properties.description: 600 block of 27th Ave NE, MinneapolisIndividual PlotsThe Shoreham Community Garden is tucked in the heart of Northeast Minneapolis, in the Holland neighborhood. On leased space from CP Rail, the garden flourishes at one end of a landscaped avenue with a volunteer-built tot lot on the other. In addition to the plots lush with zinnias, cosmos, tomatoes, strawberries, and corn we have a small orchard – pears, plums, and cherries – that we maintain collectively. Along the fence are lilacs, yarrow, and other favorites. Be our guest: relax at the picnic table under the grapevine arbor and meet Northeast residents who consider the garden a home away from home.

properties.name: Rainbow Terrace Community Garden
properties.description: 710 Plymouth Ave North, MinneapolisFood Production and Beautification

properties.name: Redeemer Community Garden
properties.description: 366 Logan Ave N. MinneapolisFood Production, Community Building, Beautification, YouthHarriet started RCG in July 2008, volunteering to experiment in getting food from a Minnesota garden and practice living the 'slow life.'  Our purpose is to enable Redeemer Community and area residents to enjoy nature, build community, and learn about gardening.  Our mission is to support neighborhood in creating and maintaining community gardens in which residents can grow their own food, foster independence, compassion, knowledge and respect for all, including children.  We are committed to providing an environment where all families are valued, supported, and encouraged.

properties.name: Richfield Community Garden
properties.description: 28th Avenue S and County Rd 62 (58 1/2 St), MinneapolisFood Production, Individual PlotsWood Lake Nature Center has managed a community garden since 1980. Originally sited on land taken by the north-south runway, the garden was relocated to Minneapolis Airport Commission (MAC) land; we were even fortunate enough to have the good soil moved there from the old site. We obtain a water permit yearly from the city, so it is truly a community garden since many communities help us. Wells Fargo Bank co-sponsors us and helps cover the costs of water, a portable toilet, and waste disposal. There are 192 plots, 15 X 20 feet each, with fourteen water spigots.

properties.name: Saint Anthony Park Community Garden
properties.description: At Robbins and Raymond Ave, St. PaulBeautification, Food Production, Individual Plots The Saint Anthony Park Community Garden was established in 1981 by neighborhood gardening enthusiasts on land leased from Burlington Northern Railroad. Over the years, and with lots of community assistance, the garden grew to ninety-six plots. In 1998 the land was purchased from the railroad by the Saint Anthony Park Community Council with funds raised by gardeners, local businesses, and government grants. The garden is designated as organic, with perennial plots, plowed plots, and flower plots. Gardeners pay an annual fee which includes access to a watering system. A volunteer coordinating team manages the garden.

properties.name: Shalom Garden
properties.description: 2819-23 15th Avenue S, MinneapolisFood Production, Individual PlotsResidents started Shalom Garden ten years ago on a vacant lot owned by the Minneapolis Community Development Agency (MCDA). In the beginning, several truck loads of woodchips were spread across the lot and 15 raised bed gardens were established. In 2000, the raised beds were removed and the entire lot was used, due to demand. In 2001 MCDA told gardeners to purchase the property or give it up for housing development. The Green Institute bought the garden in 2002, ensuring its future and provided a sign and mailbox. Recently, gardeners joined the Minnesota Horticulture Society. Future plans include new fencing, an on-site water source, other improvements. Visit us again to see our progress!

properties.name: Sisters Camelot Community Garden

properties.name: Soo Line Community Garden
properties.description: 2845 Garfield Ave S, MinneapolisYouth Programming, Beautification, Food Production, Food Donation, Individual PlotsLocated in Whittier Neighborhood, Soo Line Community Garden (SLCG) begins its growing season as one of the premier gardens in Minneapolis. Before 1991, the site was marginal urban land, a grassy field strewn with litter and broken glass. Today over 100 gardeners have transformed the area into a lush, green community asset. On summer evenings, SLCG attracts visitors to its open space and natural beauty. Children play in the paths while adults garden quietly or chat with neighbors. SLCG's presence has stabilized and enhanced the area, stimulated local businesses, and provided residents with a healthy and safe green space.

properties.name: South St. Paul Parks Community Garden
properties.description: 200 South St & First Ave S at McMorrow Field South St. Paul Food Production   The  South St. Paul Parks and  Recreation Department will be renting 15' x 20' community garden plots at the west end of McMorrow Field at 200 South Street. Rental rates include tax and will be  $15.98  (age 18 and over), and $10.65 (age 55 and over).  Those who have successfully maintained a garden plot in 2008 have first priority for sign-up beginning March 2-13.  All other residents will have an opportunity to  rent a plot, beginning March 16.  Non-residents may rent a plot  for $21.30 (adults); and  $15.98 (seniors),  beginning April 1.  For more information call, Parks and Recreation, 651-306-3690 or stop by the Central Square Community Center (100 - 7th Ave. No.) to sign up.   *note: plot prices are from 2008 and may change

properties.name: The Garden of Good Hearts
properties.description:
Congress and South Wabasha, St. PaulBeautificationThe Garden of Good Hearts (GGH), a neighborhood flower garden, is a classic example of the community coming before the community garden. In 1992 a dozen West Side residents gathered to discuss a weedy, debris-filled lot in the neighborhood, giving birth to the Riverview Garden Club (RGC) and the Garden of Good Hearts. The GGH is a valuable resource for the community to appreciate nature, and come together in friendship to beautify the neighborhood. Now over seventy households support the RGC & the GGH. Please visit our urban oasis. 
 
The Garden of Good Hearts has won the MN Green Award for "Excellence in Community Gardening: in 1998 from MSHS as well as the 
Best Garden of Beauty award from Sustainable Resources Urban Lands Program
 

Ella Thayer 
(RGC Leadership -- Riverview Garden Club) designate regional finalist in Gardener's Supply Company, Garden Crusader contest.  (donated $200 cert to Rio Vista Cmty Veg Gdn)
UMN Adult Leadership award in 2002 from Ramsey County 4-H Youth Development Program
2006 received Gold Bloom Gardening Advocate award from St. Paul Parks
 
RGC co-sponsored a community cookbook, "A Bend in the River, A Place on the Hearth" with the West Side Safe Neighborhood Council in 1997.

properties.name: The Peaceful Patch
properties.description: 2444 11th Ave S, MinneapolisBeautification, Individual PlotsPlants and friendships flourish in the Peaceful Patch Community Garden. The idea for the garden began when a couple of neighbors were tired of seeing trash and vagrants on this vacant lot. In 1993 these neighbors cleaned up the lot, tilled the soil, and planted. It gave a whole new look to the block, and other neighbors expressed appreciation and added plants. We’ve had a lot of fun over the years trying to create an urban Eden; in the process we’ve gotten to know a lot of people in our four-block area. Our focus is on building community.

properties.name: Sabathani Community Garden
properties.description: 310 East 38th St, MinneapolisFood productionSabathani's garden is part of Sabathani Community Center.  The mission of the center is "to strengthen children, youth, and families and build the capacity of the community we serve."  The community garden fits into this mission by building the community of gardeners (60 people + their families), providing plots to programs in the center for youth education, teaching neighbors how to grow their own food, and therapy for physically challenged program participants.   Gardeners reflect the community in their diverse cultures, races, ethnicity and language.  We are particularly proud to host the Zenteotl Project.  This group of neighbors are teaching and preserving indigenous Mexican traditions beginning with the role of corn and extending to art, dance, spirituality, and culture.   The garden is run and organized by the gardeners themselves.  Several events build community, including workdays, potlucks, and an end of year harvest and corn festival.

properties.name: SACA Garden of Hope
properties.description: 40th and Jackson, Columbia HeightsFood Production

properties.name: Salem Hills Park Community Garden
properties.description: 1642 Upper 55th St E, Inver Grove HeightsYouth, Food ProductionThe Inver Grove Heights Parks and Recreation Department built a community garden in Salem Hills Park as part of a grant from Dakota County Public Health and the Statewide Health Improvement Program (SHIP).  The City partnered with two third grade classrooms at Salem Hills Elementary School to provide them with their own plots.  The students began growing vegetables in the classroom, participated in a youth-oriented Master Gardener class and utilized square-foot planting in their garden.  Their next venture is a bean tent!  They will share some of the produce in the school's lunches this fall.   The remaining plots consist of an intergenerational plot that will be shared with some Inver Grove Heights seniors and our summer parks and rec Kids R.O.C.K program and some plots for low-income families.  Gardening has arrived in Inver Grove Heights!

4224 42nd Ave, Minneapolis
