properties.name: The Seward Youth Peace Garden
properties.description: 2309 28th Ave S-Seward Montessori School, MinneapolisYouth Programming, Food Production, Food DonationThe Seward Youth Peace Garden, founded in 1997, evolved from a strong collaborative effort between Seward Montessori School, the Seward Neighborhood Group, Matthews Parks and the United States Department of Agriculture. The goal of this not-for-profit youth development project was to create a small-scale urban farm where youth, ages 9-13, could learn to grow their own organic vegetables and flowers to sell at markets in their local community. Profits from vegetable and flower sales are distributed to youth as a stipend based on the number of the hours they contributed to the program. Come see all that we’re growing at the Garden!

properties.name: Skidmore Park Community Garden
properties.description: 1085 4th St E, St. PaulFood ProductionSkidmore Park Community Garden, established in 2009, has 25 fully accessible raised beds and a conveniently located water source.  The community garden, developed by local gardeners and youth, sits on a century-old St. Paul park.  Two native beds line the front of the garden, a large center bed constructed with vintage Saint Paul city street pavers serves as an education garden, and 24 raised beds provide garden space for individual gardeners.  Seven large cottonwood trees frame the outside of the park.  Projects in 2011 include developing a system for on-site composting, installation of a 19th century chicken coop for garden storage, and construction of an information kiosk.  Recipient of a 2010 Sustainable Saint Paul Park award, Skidmore Park Community Garden provides an opportunity for education and local food production.

properties.name: SPROUT Garden
properties.description: 1471 Minnehaha Ave W., St. PaulFood ProductionSPROUT seeks to create a sustained collaboration between community members and university students by planting community gardens that are maintained by students that supply community members with fresh produce; and by organizing community events (such as workshops, potlucks, trainings, film viewings, discussions…) that are accessible (economically, geographically) to community members, and university students, faculty and staff. SPROUT donates the organic produce grown in its gardens to elders in the neighborhood through the Hamline Midway Elders (a Block Nurse Program) and uses land owned by the Hamline United Methodist Church for its primary food growing site. Another primary focus of SPROUT is to educate its members on how to grow their own food, as well as to engage in a process of self-education about the various food issues in which students are implicated, and which they have the power to affect.

properties.name: SPROUT Garden
properties.description: 1514 Englewood Ave, St PaulFood ProductionSPROUT seeks to create a sustained collaboration between community members and university students by planting community gardens that are maintained by students that supply community members with fresh produce; and by organizing community events (such as workshops, potlucks, trainings, film viewings, discussions…) that are accessible (economically, geographically) to community members, and university students, faculty and staff. SPROUT donates the organic produce grown in its gardens to elders in the neighborhood through the Hamline Midway Elders (a Block Nurse Program) and uses land owned by the Hamline United Methodist Church for its primary food growing site. Another primary focus of SPROUT is to educate its members on how to grow their own food, as well as to engage in a process of self-education about the various food issues in which students are implicated, and which they have the power to affect.

properties.name: The Soul Patch
properties.description: 912 SW 1st Ave, Little Falls Food Production The Soul Patch is a 100% donation garden that provides fresh, locally grown produce to the clients of the Morrison County Food Shelf.

properties.name: Southside Star Community Garden
properties.description: 32nd Ave between 41st and 42nd Street, MinneapolisFood productionThe Southside Star Community Garden was started in December, 2008,when a residentposted a message on the neighborhood’s E-Democracy listserv. During 2009, a workinggroup sought input from the community, and went through the necessary steps to obtaininsurance, and a permit, to break ground in the spring of 2010 at the site at 32nd Ave. between 41st and 42nd St in south Minneapolis. The first year, membership was limited to residents of Standish, Ericsson, Howe, and Hiawatha neighborhoods. In later years, membership will be open to anyone. The garden is a place to grow food and beautiful flowers, and has been a community effort from the start.

properties.name: Ss Martha and Mary Community Garden
properties.description: Ss Martha and Mary Episcopal Church4180 Lexington Ave S, EaganFood production2010 was our first year for the community garden.  We offer plots of 12x20 feet.  The fee for the garden is $35 per summer, which helps offset the cost of water for the church.For 2011, we will have 8 plots.  The purpose of the garden is to help the 360 Communities Food Shelf with fresh vegetables and fruit.  Additionally, we plan to encourage participants to share the produce of the gardens with disadvantaged residents of Dakota County.  Our agreement with the gardeners will include an expected contribution of their bounty.  Each gardener is responsible for his/her plot, and plots can be shared by more than one gardener.

properties.name: St Olaf Community Campus Resource and Training Gardens
properties.description: 30th and Emerson Ave N, MinneapolisCommunal food productionThe mission of the SOCC Resource and Training Gardens is to build community, reconnect people to the Creation's healing energy and to each other, inspire local food system business development, healthy eating, youth development, connecting the generations, etc.  We are a MPLS Local Food Resource Hub site (part of the Northside Hub) and a member of the Northside Healthy Eating Coalition (a Blue Cross Blue Shield "Healthy Eating MN" initiative).  Access to fresh fruits and vegetables and helping people form habits of healthy eating in cmmunity is a part of our work together.  All who eat food are welcome to participate and help develop new areas of interest around food and gardening.  ALL SKILL LEVELS WELCOME!  Come teach, learn, exercies your gardening/cooking/eating/community skills!  For more info and to become involved contact Steve Loman C:612-508-1138 email: lomensocc@gmail.com

properties.name: Stryker Avenue Community Garden
properties.description: Stryker and Elizabeth, St. PaulFood Production

properties.name: Summer Street Community Garden
properties.description: near 900 Summer Street NE, MinneapolisFood productionSummer Street Community garden is a well-established, organic garden on a cul-de-sac near a park in the St. Anthony East neighborhood. We have a common tool shed and community work days to help maintain our common areas.   We have a good mix of gardeners with a wide variety of ages, backgrounds, and gardening experience!

properties.name: Talmadge Crossing Garden
properties.description: Talmadge Ave SE between 20th and 21st, MinneapolisBeautifcationThe goal of the Talmadge Crossing Garden is beautication of a popular place for neighbors to walk, jog, and bike, and to encourage people to do so.   We also want to restore land depleted by BNSF's use of herbicides and eliminate 6' noxious weeks, while keeping plants at 18" height, within the safety guidelines for railroad crossings.

properties.name: Totem Town Community Garden
properties.description: 391 South Winthrop, St. PaulBeautification, Food Production, Food Donation, Individual Plots The Totem Town Community Garden draws fifty gardeners on a two-acre tract administered by the Ramsey County Corrections Department; the Corrections staff have been great partners to keep community gardening growing. In 1998 gardeners took over operations, and in 2006 the District One Community Council became our sponsor. Gardeners have added three plant-covered trellises, a curving hedge, a salvaged plant garden, native plantings, and a small orchard. In 2006, third grade and high school students planted lively and colorful raised beds, and in 2007 we have two plots for food shelf donations.

properties.name: Triangle Garden
properties.description: 42nd & Humboldt Ave N, MinneapolisBeautificationA triangle of cracked cement and ugly weeds in the middle of an odd intersection was removed by a Minneapolis city crew in 1997 at the request of the Camden Garden Club. The Triangle Garden was created with rescued flowers from neighborhood houses scheduled to be moved, plants donated through Minnesota Green, and perennials from the yards of garden club members and friends. Triangle Garden plants include: peony, columbine, Missouri primrose, hardy geranium, iris, phlox, hollyhock, shrub rose, yarrow, Oriental lilies and one Pasque flower. We enjoy the “thank-yous” from passersby while weeding in this pleasant garden.

properties.name: Triangle Park Community Garden
properties.description: Triangle Park, off Main Street and Rouillard Ave, Rogers Food production, beautification Please see our website at www.locavore.cityofrogers.org

properties.description:
10658 210th St. Lakeville
Food production, donation, community building, individual plots
The garden plots at Trinity Evangelical Free church started in Spring of 2009.  Members of the church organized the tilling and were given 20'x20' plots to work on.  There is appoximately 3-4 acres of land to use.   Our source of water comes from a small lake nearby which makes growing easier and sustainable.  We are located off Highway 70 between the highway and the church.  We have established the gardens to give those who like to garden an opportunity to grow.

properties.name: United Community Garden
properties.description: 301 3rd St, Moose LakeFood production and donation

properties.name: University of St Thomas Stewardship Garden
properties.description: backyards of 2140, 2144 and 2150 Summit Ave, St PaulCommunal food production, donationCG DescriptionThe Stewardship Garden, located at the University of St Thomas, was established in 2010 with the three-fold goal of providing fresh, organic produce to nearby low-income communities, education and research opportunities, and community building. We meet weekly throughout the summer to communally work our plots, as well as host community events focusing on gardening, food and sustainability. A portion of the produce is donated to local food shelves, and the rest is available for the friends, relatives, neighbors, students and professors that are involved. We welcome any and all! Please visit our facebook page or contact us directly at uststewardshipgarden@gmail.com

properties.name: Urban Farming 12th and Morgan North
properties.description:
1119 Morgan Avenue North
Minneapolis, MN 55411 
Community-Building, Youth Education, Adult/Family education, Horticultural Therapy, Food Production, Beautification, Food Donation
 
The Urban Farming Garden at 12th and Morgan North was established in 2008 as part of the mission of the national non-profit organization "Urban Farming" to end hunger in our generation.  An approximate area of 3500 square feet was filled with 110 cubic yards of compost donated by Creekside Soils.  In addition, many volunteers gathered to prepare the garden and to plant vegetables that first season.  Throughout the summer, volunteers including area residents tend to garden.  Food grown in the garden is available to all.  Much of the produce goes directly to people in the area, and some is dropped off at the food shelf.  All are welcome!

properties.name: Urban Ventures Community Garden
properties.description: 4th Avenue and 29th Street Minneapolis, MNYouth Focus, Donation FocusFour years ago we planted an orchard. This was used to illustrate simple concepts such as where fruit comes from, simple botany, and local food systems. Eventually, the project was expanded to include larger vegetable gardens and a more structured teaching environment. As part of the curriculum, students in Urban Ventures programs learn where their food comes from, various uses for each plant, and nutrition, among other topics. It serves as both a beautification garden for the community as well as a teaching garden for local youth. Will Gove, a Honeywell employee and community member with his heart in the right place, gave generously to start the garden and to maintain it, speaking to his commitment to the youth of Minneapolis.

properties.name: U-WHO Community Garden
properties.description: 2407 Upton Ave N, MinneapolisFood production, food donationA couple neighbors noticed an empty lot and found the owner through tax records.  The owners gave us permission to plant a row of vegetables.  In 2009, we expanded to four rows with donations of vegetable seedlings.   Several folks have volunteered to water twice a week.   The Emerge crew visited twice to pull weeds and spread woodchips in August.  The purpose of the garden is simple: make fresh food available to neighbors who lack access to it elsewhere.

properties.name: Waite House Community Garden
properties.description: 2529 13th Ave S, MinneapolisYouthThe Waite House Community Garden is primarily used by the Waite House Youth Program, with 60 kids ages 5-17, and by their parents through the Wellness Program.  These two programs use the garden as an educational tool in areas of growing, ecology, and nutrition.  Adult participants have been very enthusiastic about sharing their knowledge and teaching their children more about food.  We expect the garden to grow into a vital resource for families and a valued asset in the community.     Remaining space in the garden is available to residents of the Phillips Community who have a strong interest in nutrition, community engagement, and land stewardship.  The process of coming together to grow food for the community will strengthen ties between neighbors.  We believe that there is a wealth of knowledge in our community and that many people with the skill and desire to gorw their own food are looking for a space to do so.

properties.name: Waite Park Community Garden
properties.description: Johnson St NE and 36th Ave NE, NW corner, Minneapolis Beautification, Food Production, Individual Plots   Some Quick facts on our Waite Park Neighborhood Garden: The garden was established in 1997.Today the garden has 64 members.The garden occupies about 20,000 sq feet and includes room for additional plots. There are 71 garden plots each totaling 144 sq. ft. most of which are 12'x12'. Two of the plots are handicap accessible and have been built 3 feet above ground totallin 72 sq. ft. in size.The garden has its own metered City water service. To find out more about our garden, visit: http://sites.google.com/site/wpccngwm/

properties.name: Wapahasa's Prairie Community Garden
properties.description: Parks Avenue, one block north of Highway 61 on east end of Lake Winona, Winona, MN Food Production, Individual Plots   Winona Community Garden Plots formed in March 2008 to find usable land in our city and form an organizational structure and programming.  We formed in response to Frozen River Film Festival's Next Steps program, offering grant monies to community projects inspired by the film festival.  Our mission is "providing support for growing organic vegetables in a community setting."   In fall 2008, Winona Health, our local hospital and health clinic, invited us to submit a proposal for a community garden on some of their newly acuired land.  Our detailed proposal was accepted in March 2009 and we offered 28 vegetable plots and 20 flower border strips in the 2009 season.   The gardeners voted to name the garden Wapahasa's Prairie, the original Dakota name for Winona.    For 2010, we have expanded to 50 vegetable plots and 40 flower border strips with approximately 65 plot renting families and individuals participating.    We have a 6 member Advisory Board, a part-time hired Garden Coordinator and several special events throughout the year: a seed and catalogue exchange in February, two spring work days in April, informal sunset gatherings weekly in summer, fall harvest festival and late fall clean-up workday.    We're located at the east end of Lake Winona beneath the Sugar Loaf bluff, and any of the proud gardeners will show you around when you stop by.    For contact information, please contact Gardening Matters at 612-492-8964 or info@gardeningmatters.org

properties.name: Youth Farm and Market Project - Lyndale Neighborhood
properties.description: 3110 Blaisdell Ave S (Charles Horn Terrace Garden)Youth Programming, Beautification, Food Production at one of three garden sites in Lyndale NeighborhoodYouth Farm and Market Project is a non-profit organization that works with youth in three Twin Cities neighborhoods to grow, cook, and sell organic produce, all the while learning leadership skills and making connections in the community. The Lyndale branch has three gardens: an herb garden at Lyndale School; the Pillsbury garden (which we hope to make into a fruit farm); and the Charles Horn Terrace Garden, which is maintained by youth farmers and international residents of the CHT apartments.

properties.name: St Olaf Community Campus Resource & Training Gardens
properties.description: The mission of the SOCC Resource and Training Gardens is to build community, reconnect people to the Creation's healing energy and to each other, inspire local food system business development, healthy eating, youth development, connecting the generations, etc.  We are a MPLS Local Food Resource Hub site (part of the Northside Hub) and a member of the Northside Healthy Eating Coalition (a Blue Cross Blue Shield "Healthy Eating MN" initiative).  Access to fresh fruits and vegetables and helping people form habits of healthy eating in cmmunity is a part of our work together.
